content.explanation:
Functions are all around us in everyday life. They model relationships between quantities in the real world.

For example:
- The cost of a cab ride as a function of distance traveled
- The height of a thrown ball as a function of time
- The temperature of a cup of coffee as a function of time since brewing

In each case, one quantity (the output) depends on another quantity (the input) in a predictable way.
content.example:
The function C(g) = 3.79g represents the cost C in dollars to buy g gallons of gasoline at $3.79 per gallon.

Domain: g ≥ 0 (you can't buy a negative amount of gas)
Range: C ≥ 0 (the cost can't be negative)
content.key_point: In real-world contexts, the domain and range often have practical limitations. For instance, time can't be negative, or a person's height can't be 20 feet.

interactive.question: A cell phone plan costs $20 per month plus $0.10 per text message. If the function C(t) represents the monthly cost when sending t text messages, what is C(50)?
